questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 12-hour history of suspected abdominal pain. The mother says that he has not had any fever, vomiting, diarrhea, or dysuria. His last bowel movement was 3 days ago and appeared hard. He was recently introduced to solid food and his diet consists of breast milk, yogurt, fruits, vegetables, and infant cereals. He is restless and cries when his abdomen is touched. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 135/min, and respirations are 35/min. The abdomen appears mildly distended. On auscultation, there are hyperactive bowel sounds. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend apple juice diluted with water
Reassure the mother and schedule follow-up in 1 month

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Infants who are transitioning from breastmilk to solid foods often present with primary constipation due to insufficient intake of fiber and fluid from the transitional diet. Primary constipation typically manifests with abdominal pain and infrequent, hard, and/or painful bowel movements. Sorbitol, which is commonly found in juice (e.g., apple, prune, pear), is a nonabsorbable disaccharide that draws water into the intestinal lumen and softens the stool. Early treatment with sorbitol-containing juices may prevent the development and exacerbation of fecal impaction. Glycerine suppositories may be used to assist in management.

Primary constipation accounts for approximately 95% of cases of constipation in children. Chronic constipation that persists despite treatment may be a sign of an underlying condition (e.g., celiac disease, hypothyroidism, spinal defects) and therefore requires further investigation.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in infant dyschezia, a condition in which healthy infants strain and/or cry for at least 10 minutes prior to defecation. Stools are typically soft or liquid and of normal frequency rather than hard and infrequent. Reassurance may also be appropriate for exclusively breastfed infants 1–6 months of age who present with constipation with no alarm symptoms and normal urine output. This 8-month-old with primary constipation requires treatment because pain during defecation may cause the child to avoid or delay a bowel movement, which can further exacerbate fecal impaction.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous fluid therapy is indicated in children with severe dehydration as a result of viral or bacterial gastroenteritis, which would cause abdominal pain. However, this infant does not have evidence of dehydration (e.g., lethargy, dry mucous membranes, tenting of skin) or other clinical features that suggest gastroenteritis (e.g., fever, diarrhea, vomiting).

D) INCORRECT:

Barium enemas are indicated in infants with suspected intussusception, which most commonly occurs in children < 2 years of age and manifests with features of mechanical bowel obstruction (e.g., abdominal pain, hyperactive bowel sounds, constipation). However, intussusception typically manifests with lethargy, paroxysms of abdominal pain that last 15–20 minutes, and a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant, none of which are seen here. Furthermore, an abdominal ultrasound would reveal a target sign at the site of intussusception.
Image Description:

Transverse view of an abdominal ultrasound in a patient with intussusception showing a so-called target sign: The invaginated portion of bowel (green overlay) resembles rings on a target, where the intestinal walls form the echogenic rings.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral administration of lubricant laxatives, such as mineral oil, may be used to treat patients with constipation. However, mineral oil is not recommended in infants because its safety and efficacy in children under 2 years of age have not been established and because of the risk of aspiration and lipoid pneumonitis.
questions.hint: This 8-month-old patient, who has recently started eating solid foods, presents with abdominal pain, infrequent, hard bowel movements, hyperactive bowel sounds, a normal ultrasound, and no alarm symptoms (e.g., fever, vomiting, diarrhea), all of which suggests primary constipation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of abdominal pain and frequent urination. Her mother reports that her daughter wet the bed the previous night and that the urine smelled bad. She was toilet-trained for 4 months and has had very few accidents since then. She takes frequent bubble baths. Her last bowel movement was 3 days ago. She was born at term after a normal gestation and has reached all developmental milestones. She has had two upper respiratory infections within the last 6 months that resolved without treatment. Her 12-year-old brother has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the abdomen shows mild suprapubic tenderness. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase, nitrite, and blood; urinalysis shows white blood cells and gram-negative rods. Which of the following risk factors most likely contributed to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bubble baths can contribute to the development of vulvovaginitis in prepubertal children. Due to low estrogen levels, vulvar skin and vaginal mucosa are thin and susceptible to irritants (e.g., bubble baths, perfumed soaps), which disrupt the natural acidic pH balance and predispose to inflammation and infection. While vulvovaginitis can manifest with increased urinary frequency and pain in the lower abdomen and/or suprapubic region, it usually causes pruritus, redness and/or a burning sensation. Bubble baths are not a risk factor for UTIs.

B) CORRECT:

Constipation is a known risk factor for UTIs in children. Prolonged fecal retention leads to bladder dysfunction and urinary stasis, which in turn promotes bacterial overgrowth. This child has not had a bowel movement in 3 days, which has likely contributed to her UTI. Causes of constipation in children include social stressors (e.g., family conflicts and school pressures), low fiber diet, dehydration, lack of physical activity, and underlying conditions (e.g., Hirschsprung disease, hypothyroidism, and cystic fibrosis). Constipation is especially common in children who have recently started toilet training (e.g., withholding maneuvers because of unavailability of toilets).

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in male newborns and are often identified in utero via ultrasound. Although congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract are a risk factor for recurrent pediatric UTIs, PUVs are found almost exclusively in boys and typically cause symptoms early in infancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Respiratory tract infection (RTI) can lead to UTI if the causative pathogen is transmitted to the urinary tract. This is more common in recently toilet-trained children because they often have poor genital and hand hygiene, which makes transmission of microorganisms from mouth to genitals more likely. Although this patient has a history of recent RTIs, the gram-negative rods found on urinalysis are unlikely to be due to an RTI. A different risk factor is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with diabetes mellitus are predisposed to UTI because abundant glucose in the urine acts as a nutrient source and encourages bacterial overgrowth. Moreover, this condition can cause varying degrees of immune dysfunction, which further predisposes patients to infection. Although this patient has a family history of diabetes mellitus, she does not have common features of the condition, such as weight loss, polydipsia, polyuria, or glucosuria.
questions.hint: This toilet-trained child presents with suprapubic tenderness, urinary frequency, strong-smelling urine, and urinary incontinence, raising suspicion for urinary tract infection (UTI). Abnormal findings on urine dipstick (e.g., nitrite) and urinalysis (e.g., bacteriuria) confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has had 1–2 bowel movements a week for the past month. Her mother has also noticed that the child has been straining and passing hard stools during her bowel movements.  She has been attending a daycare center for 2 months and she has recently begun toilet training. She was born at term and the neonatal period was uncomplicated. Her 6-year-old brother has Hirschsprung disease. She is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Rectal examination shows a large and hard fecal mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism (↑ TSH levels) may also cause chronic constipation due to downregulated bowel motility. However, this patient is missing further symptoms of hypometabolism such as weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, hair loss, and fatigue.

B) INCORRECT:

A barium enema is indicated in patients with suspected Hirschsprung disease. It is usually performed in addition to x-ray studies to localize and determine the length of the aganglionic segment prior to surgery and typically shows a change in caliber along the affected intestinal segment. While this patient has a positive family history of Hirschsprung disease, she has no history of failed passage of meconium within 48 hours after birth, bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and/or growth faltering. In addition, a rectal exam in patients with Hirschprung disease typically shows a tight anal canal with an empty ampulla and the squirt sign.

C) INCORRECT:

Sorbitol-containing juices or purees (e.g., prune, apple, pear) may be sufficient to soften the stool, particularly in infants with acute constipation. However, diet changes alone are not sufficient in patients with fecal impaction. A more effective therapeutic agent is required in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Anorectal manometry is indicated in suspected Hirschsprung disease. While this patient has a positive family history of Hirschsprung disease, she has no history of failed passage of meconium within 48 hours after birth, bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and/or growth faltering. In addition, a rectal exam in patients with Hirschprung disease typically shows a tight anal canal with an empty ampulla and the squirt sign.

E) CORRECT:

Prompt laxative therapy with osmotics such as polyethylene glycol is the treatment of choice in children > 6 months of age with primary (functional) constipation and fecal impaction, which typically occur during weaning or the toilet training phase. Osmotic agents soften the stool by drawing water into the gastrointestinal lumen. Osmotics disimpact the bowel contents initially, but are also an effective maintenance therapy to prevent complications such as anal fissures and recurrent constipation. Symptom relief can additionally be achieved by dietary changes, such as an increase in fiber and fluid intake and support in regular toileting habits.

A poor response to the treatment options mentioned above or the presence of any alarming clinical features warrants further investigation to exclude an underlying disorder.

F) INCORRECT:

A lifelong gluten-free diet is the treatment of choice for gluten-sensitive enteropathy. This patient has constipation rather than chronic diarrhea and lacks further symptoms of celiac disease such as abdominal bloating, fatigue, or weight loss. Celiac disease occasionally manifests with constipation and other minor symptoms. However, laboratory investigations in these patients will show evidence of malabsorption (iron, folate, and cobalamin deficiency), which helps differentiate it from functional constipation.

G) INCORRECT:

An abdominal x-ray is performed to exclude organic causes of constipation and is the best initial test in suspected Hirschsprung disease. While this patient has a positive family history of Hirschsprung disease, she has no history of failed passage of meconium within 48 hours after birth, bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and/or growth faltering. In addition, a rectal exam in patients with Hirschprung disease typically shows a tight anal canal with an empty ampulla and the squirt sign.
questions.hint: This child has no alarming clinical features like blood in the stool, growth faltering, or a distended abdomen.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-month history of stool incontinence. He was potty-trained at 4 years but now soils in his clothes 1–2 times a month and does not seem to notice when he needs to go to the bathroom. He now sleeps with pull-up diapers at night and he frequently urinates in them. He has large, hard stools and painful bowel movements once a week. They moved to a new town 5 months ago and the patient has had trouble adjusting. He also started school a few months ago, which according to the mother “only made things worse.” He has bronchial asthma well controlled with a corticosteroid inhaler, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder for which he takes methylphenidate. He eats a regular diet but dislikes vegetables apart from green peas and potatoes. He is at the 50th percentile for weight and 25th percentile for height. His temperature is 36.7°C (96.1°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is mildly distended and there is firmness to palpation in the left lower quadrant; there is no guarding or rebound. Digital rectal examination shows a normal sphincter tone. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the abdomen can be used to evaluate for potential causes of encopresis (e.g., fecal mass in the rectosigmoid colon) in patients who have no history of constipation or in whom an abdominal and/or rectal digital examination is not possible (e.g., due to obesity, refusal). This patient's history and physical examination findings are consistent with constipation, for which an abdominal x-ray is not required. In patients with constipation, the digital rectal examination may show a distended rectum filled with stool. However, a normal digital rectal exam does not exclude the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A high-fiber diet may be considered for the management and prevention of constipation, which this patient has. Although patients with constipation benefit from long-term dietary interventions, another more urgent management step is required at this time.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical and physical findings are consistent with retentive encopresis, the most common type of encopresis. Symptoms typically develop as a result of underlying constipation and stool impaction, with consequent overflow past the impaction and soiling of underwear. Retentive encopresis develops when the urge to defecate is suppressed; triggering situations include starting school (e.g., due to limited time, lack of privacy, unhygienic toilets), and avoidance of painful defecation (e.g., constipation, anal fissures). In younger children, constipation can develop during potty training or the transition to solid food. Treatment consists of fecal disimpaction with enemas or oral agents (polyethylene glycol), followed by maintenance laxative therapy for 6–24 months. An ongoing healthy high-fiber diet along with age-appropriate physical activity is also recommended. For children with encopresis, additional behavioral interventions (e.g., regular toilet regimen, positive reinforcement), cognitive behavioral therapy, and biofeedback training (to improve control of perianal musculature) should be considered.

Encopresis itself can cause significant psychological distress in children. Parents should therefore be advised to support their children and provide positive feedback and reinforcement throughout the entire duration of treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Biofeedback is an adjuvant technique in the management of retentive encopresis that helps patients to improve control of their anal sphincter and perianal muscles. Before considering biofeedback training, however, another step is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up may be appropriate in children who have just started toilet training and still have incomplete bowel control (typically in those < 4 years of age). This 6-year-old patient, however, was toilet-trained 2 years ago and has had good bowel control until 3 months ago, which suggests a nonphysiologic cause of his symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the lumbosacral spine can be performed in a patient with lumbar spinal cord lesions (e.g., spina bifida occulta, meningomyelocele), which can manifest with fecal and urinary incontinence. However, this patient has no other signs of a spinal cord lesion (e.g., abnormal sphincter tone, muscle weakness). His presentation is more consistent with constipation, which is the most likely cause of his fecal incontinence. Because of the close proximity of the rectum, anus, and urinary tract, urinary incontinence often occurs simultaneously with constipation (e.g., due to compression of the bladder, changes in neural stimulation to the bladder and pelvic floor).
questions.hint: According to the DSM-5 criteria, encopresis is defined as the involuntary elimination of feces in children ≥ 4 years in inappropriate settings for their developmental age (e.g., in their clothes, on the floor), occurring more than once a month for ≥ 3 months. Encopresis is classified as either retentive or nonretentive. This patient’s history (large, hard stools with painful bowel movements, nocturia) and physical examination findings (mild abdominal distension, firmness in the left lower quadrant) indicate that he has retentive encopresis.

questions.text:
The parents of a healthy 2-year-old girl are attempting to establish toilet training. Despite parental use of a positive reward system, the child refuses to use the toilet. Instead, she often crosses her legs to avoid a bowel movement and later hides behind the couch to pass the stool. Bowel movements occur once or twice per day, and the stool consistency is soft.
What is the most appropriate next step for this child?

choices.text: Continue toilet training with positive reinforcement
Suspend toilet training for several weeks
Give a glycerin suppository, and continue toilet training
Initiate oral polyethylene glycol once daily, and continue toilet training
Continue toilet training, and encourage the parents to delay diaper changes for progressively longer periods of time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If toilet training is continued, the current behaviors are likely to persist despite positive reinforcement.

B) CORRECT:

Readiness for toilet training varies from child to child, and expectations differ among cultures and families. Signs of readiness include demonstrating a desire to participate in toilet training and being able to stay dry for several hours, to sit on the potty, and to communicate the need to use the potty. Once a child has shown these signs of readiness, she should be introduced to a potty chair or toilet.

Positive reinforcement should be used to encourage a child during toilet training; however, a child who is not ready for toilet training may show signs of stool withholding, such as a change in posture or gait to prevent passage of stool or avoidance of a caregiver in order to pass stool in a favorite location. The best advice for a child with stool withholding is to temporarily discontinue toilet training (including all reminders and pressure) and resume in several weeks.

Key learning point: The best approach for a young toddler who withholds stool to avoid using the toilet is to suspend toilet training (including all reminders and pressure) for several weeks.

C) INCORRECT:

Medication such as glycerin suppositories are appropriate in cases of underlying constipation; however, this patient shows no signs or symptoms of constipation.

D) INCORRECT:

Medication such as polyethylene glycol are appropriate in cases of underlying constipation; however, this patient shows no signs or symptoms of constipation.

E) INCORRECT:

Negative reinforcement (e.g., delaying a diaper change) or punishment may exacerbate these behaviors and lead to chronic constipation or encopresis.

questions.text:
A 30-month-old boy is brought in for evaluation of hard stools. His mother reports that he was having a soft, formed bowel movement daily until about 6 months ago, when he gradually started to stool less frequently and subsequently started passing a hard stool every 3 to 4 days. His bowel movements appeared painful and required straining, and occasionally his mother noted a small amount of blood on the toilet paper after wiping.
About 4 months ago, he was started on polyethylene glycol (PEG) by one of your colleagues. Since then, he has had one hard, large-caliber stool every 2 to 3 days, and his mother has not noticed any more blood with stooling. He has not had any nausea or vomiting but does intermittently appear to be bloated.
He has not had any changes in diet since his stooling patterns first changed, and his mother describes him as a “great eater” who consumes a wide variety of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and meats. He drinks 14 ounces of low-fat milk daily and otherwise drinks water.
The patient is otherwise healthy; he was born full-term and passed meconium within the first 24 hours of life. He takes no medications. His family history is significant for Crohn disease (father) and type 1 diabetes (maternal cousin).
On examination, he is happy and interactive, with normal vital signs. His growth chart shows that his weight has fallen from the 40th percentile at his visit 4 months ago to the 25th percentile today; he has maintained linear growth along the 45th percentile.
He has no oral ulcers, and his neck examination is unremarkable. His abdomen is slightly distended but nontender and without rebound; a moderate stool burden is palpated in the left lower quadrant. On digital rectal examination, the patient has normal rectal tone and hard stool palpable in the rectal vault. Examination of the back reveals no dimples or abnormalities. The rest of the examination is normal, including the deep-tendon reflexes.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient’s evaluation?

choices.text: Measure levels of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA
Reassure the family without performing additional testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anorectal manometry can be used to assess anal sphincter pressure and rectal pressure. It can be helpful in the evaluation of constipation when nonobstructive dysfunction (e.g., aganglionosis in Hirschsprung disease) is suspected. However, this patient does not exhibit the typical characteristics of Hirschsprung disease (he passed meconium within the first 24 hours of life, and constipation started after one month of life); in addition, he has normal rectal tone on examination, making anorectal manometry unlikely to be beneficial in his workup.

B) CORRECT:

Constipation can typically be diagnosed on the basis of history and physical examination alone, with further workup reserved only for patients with alarm symptoms. In this patient’s age group, red flags in pediatric constipation should warrant further evaluation. When a child has uncomplicated constipation without alarm symptoms (as this patient initially did), the most appropriate management is an oral bowel regimen. Many children require an initial bowel clean-out with oral osmotic laxatives (such as polyethylene glycol or magnesium citrate), often in conjunction with a stimulant laxative (such as bisacodyl or senna). The clean-out is followed by regular maintenance therapy with an osmotic laxative (with or without a stimulant laxative) to ensure subsequent regular passage of soft bowel movements. If the patient’s constipation does not respond to laxative therapy as expected or if alarm symptoms develop, further workup is warranted.

In this case, the patient’s constipation has not responded to osmotic laxative therapy, he has new evidence of poor growth, and his family history is significant for autoimmune diseases. Celiac disease should therefore be considered, and the most appropriate next step would be to measure levels of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody (tTG-IgA) and total IgA. Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition in which genetically susceptible individuals react to dietary gluten (present in wheat, rye, and barley). The clinical presentation is variable and can include both gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, abdominal distention, diarrhea, constipation, weight loss) and other signs and symptoms (e.g., anemia, dermatitis herpetiformis, short stature).

In patients >2 years of age, the recommended test for celiac disease is measurement of the tTG-IgA level. A total IgA level should be obtained at the same time to identify individuals with IgA deficiency. If the patient is found to be IgA deficient, further workup for celiac disease would be warranted (with deamidated gliadin peptide antibody-IgG [DGP-IgG]). Research has shown that testing with tTG-IgA alone might not be accurate for children younger than 2 years of age. When testing is indicated in this age group, guidelines from NASPGHAN (the North American Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition) recommend obtaining both tTG-IgA and DGP-IgG levels to improve diagnostic accuracy. However, guidelines from the American College of Gastroenterology still recommend obtaining only a tTG-IgA level unless IgA deficiency is found. Patients whose serologic test results raise suspicion for celiac disease should be referred to a pediatric gastroenterologist for upper endoscopy with biopsy.

Key learning point: In a child who presents with poor weight gain and constipation that has been unresponsive to oral laxative therapy, the next step in workup should include measuring levels of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody and total IgA to evaluate for celiac disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Although abdominal radiography would be important to consider if a patient had fecal impaction with obstruction, it is not otherwise indicated (or recommended) for routine diagnosis or monitoring of constipation.

D) INCORRECT:

A spinal MRI should be considered in patients with evidence of spinal cord anomalies, such as an abnormal lower-extremity neurologic examination or sacral dimple. Given that this patient has no symptoms that suggest a neurologic disorder (he has normal deep-tendon reflexes and a normal back examination), a spinal MRI is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance alone is not appropriate for this patient at this time, given the evidence of alarm symptoms (poor weight gain).

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 12-hour history of suspected abdominal pain. The mother says that he has not had any fever, vomiting, diarrhea, or dysuria. His last bowel movement was 3 days ago and appeared hard. Constipation is a known risk factor for UTIs in children. Prolonged fecal retention leads to bladder dysfunction and urinary stasis, which in turn promotes bacterial overgrowth. This child has not had a bowel movement in 3 days, which has likely contributed to her UTI. Causes of constipation in children include social stressors (e.g., family conflicts and school pressures), low fiber diet, dehydration, lack of physical activity, and underlying conditions (e.g., Hirschsprung disease, hypothyroidism, and cystic fibrosis). Constipation is especially common in children who have recently started toilet training (e.g., withholding maneuvers because of unavailability of toilets).

C) INCORRECT:

Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in male newborns and are often identified in utero via ultrasound. Although congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract are a risk factor for recurrent pediatric UTIs, PUVs are found almost exclusively in boys and typically cause symptoms early in infancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Respiratory tract infection (RTI) can lead to UTI if the causative pathogen is transmitted to the urinary tract. This is more common in recently toilet-trained children because they often have poor genital and hand hygiene, which makes transmission of microorganisms from mouth to genitals more likely. Although this patient has a history of recent RTIs, the gram-negative rods found on urinalysis are unlikely to be due to an RTI. A different risk factor is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with diabetes mellitus are predisposed to UTI because abundant glucose in the urine acts as a nutrient source and encourages bacterial overgrowth. Moreover, this condition can cause varying degrees of immune dysfunction, which further predisposes patients to infection. Although this patient has a family history of diabetes mellitus, she does not have common features of the condition, such as weight loss, polydipsia, polyuria, or glucosuria.
questions.hint: This toilet-trained child presents with suprapubic tenderness, urinary frequency, strong-smelling urine, and urinary incontinence, raising suspicion for urinary tract infection (UTI). Abnormal findings on urine dipstick (e.g., nitrite) and urinalysis (e.g., bacteriuria) confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department for increased fussiness and feeding intolerance over the past 24 hours. The parents report a 2-week history of infrequent bowel movements and increasing abdominal distention. The parents report the infant passed meconium at 60 hours after birth and now has bowel movements every 5–6 days with significant straining. Physical examination shows an irritable infant with marked abdominal distention and a palpable left lower quadrant mass. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend dietary modifications and prune juice

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This infant has multiple red flags including constipation in an infant under 6 months, delayed meconium passage beyond 48 hours, significant abdominal distention, and a palpable mass suggesting fecal impaction. While the palpable mass confirms fecal impaction, abdominal radiography is indicated to assess the extent of impaction, rule out bowel obstruction, and provide diagnostic information before specialist consultation.

B) INCORRECT:

The presence of red flag features in an infant under 6 months with delayed meconium passage, confirmed fecal impaction, and acute feeding intolerance requires immediate evaluation rather than routine outpatient follow-up.

C) INCORRECT:

Dietary modifications are inappropriate for a 4-month-old infant, and functional constipation is uncommon in infants under 6 months of age. The multiple red flags and acute presentation require immediate diagnostic evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Manual disimpaction is not recommended in infants and children due to risk of colon perforation. Diagnostic evaluation should be performed first in this high-risk scenario.

E) INCORRECT:

While polyethylene glycol is preferred for functional constipation, the presence of red flag features in any constipation case requires diagnostic evaluation before initiating laxative therapy.
